name: 5-iodoindole
Reason: 5-iodoindole has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The iodine atom introduces a significant increase due to the higher molecular weight and the formation of iodine-containing compounds, which have a higher melting point than hydrogen-bonded compounds. The iodine atom can participate in hydrogen bonding, which raises the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
